content:
hello,

Test6 and validator6 don't match, my (hugly) code is ok for the test but not he validator

b = [*map(int,input().split())]

r = [j-i for i,j in zip(b,b[1:])]

inc = max(r,key=r.count)
print(inc, r,b, sep='\n', file=sys.stderr)

l = [b[0]+inc*i for i in range(len(b)-1)]

if len({*b})==2:
    print(*({*l}-{inc}))
elif len({*b}-{*l})>1:
    print(min(l,key=l.count))
else:
    print(*({*b}-{*l}))

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and simple clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solid, simple puzzle.

Suggestion: Don't define an arithmetic sequence in math language. Anyone who doesn't already know what this simple concept is, will not be able to better understand it. Instead, give an example.

An arithmetic sequence is a sequence of number such as 4, 7, 10, 13 where some value is added each time, in this case 3.

Suggestion: Don't enumerate the sequence b or mention the index of the removed item, which is irrelevant to the answer.

In this problem, you are given a sequence [b] of integers which is almost an arithmetic sequence except for one inserted value. Find the value [v] such that removing it results in an arithmetic sequence.

Solved it nicely, good idea for all modes. I'd like to approve, but I'm hesitating because the sub generator defines a string. I think what you need first is an integer for the length of the sequence, and then you can define each element as an int. I'm guessing that's because some languages need to know how many elements.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun problem, not too hard, and suited for all three modes
Thanks for the approval and the suggestion! I'll change the problem to ask for the value of the element not in the arithmetic sequence.

Thanks for the suggestion! I tried the stub
read n:int
loopline n b:int
write 0
but it gives an error with Clojure. An alternative would be
read n:int
loop n read b:int
write 0
but as that would need each sequence element to be written on a separate line, it might be unsuitable for reverse mode.

Thanks for the further suggestions and the approval!

Suggestion 1: I incorporated your definition by example into the definition in wikipedia.

Suggestion 2: This is a very nice way to describe the problem!
Thanks for the comment! I changed Validator 6 so that your code passes it. Moreover, I changed Test 8 and Validator 8 so that your code fails them.

Oh wow, how ridiculous. OK.

By the way, in another puzzle there was a bug in Clojure due to a tab character someone found, but I didn't see that here.
I changed my solution, i -> b[i], 3 more characters !
